key_title: Key to the species of Bossiaea

Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the subfamilies of Fabaceae
Key to the genera of Fabaceae subfam. Faboideae

source.author: Ross, J.H.
source.title: Bossiaea
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Ross, J.H. (1996). Bossiaea. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves always present; branches terete or sometimes slightly flattened, rarely (B. heterophylla) winged
Plants leafless (except for exstipulate scales and sometimes some juvenile leaves on young growth or at base of stems); branches flat and distinctly winged (i.e. cladodes)
Leaves opposite
Leaves alternate
Leaves ovate, 3–6 mm long
Leaves trullate or triangular to ovate, linear or linear-lanceolate, 5–28 mm long
Leaves linear to linear-lanceolate, 1–3 mm wide, on distinct petiolules to 1.5 mm long; Grampians only
Leaves trullate or triangular to ovate or lanceolate, 2–7 mm wide, sessile or almost so

Small spur on petiole (at leaflet articulation point) present on at least some leaves; stipules spreading to reflexed, inserted on opposite sides of the petiole; leaf length to width ratio >3; wing petals purplish-brown; widespread in southern Victoria (but largely absent in the Otway Ranges)
Petiole lacking spur; stipules recurved to reflexed (and somewhat V-shaped), inserted relatively close to each other; leaf length to width ratio <3; wing petals yellow; Otway Ranges
Lateral branches terminating in spines
Lateral branches not terminating in spines

Leaves orbicular or longer than wide, mostly longer than 3 mm; flowers on pedicels 5–20 mm long; corolla usually yellow and red to purplish-brown; ovary glabrous or with ciliate margins; pods ovate to oblong, 1–2 cm long, glabrous or almost so

Leaves transversely elliptic, obcordate or cordate, to 3 mm long; flowers on pedicels to 3 mm long; corolla usually uniformly bright yellow; ovary densely clothed with ferruginous hairs; pods almost circular, to 1 cm diam., densely clothed with rusty hairs
Leaves variously shaped, 3–28 mm long; unifoliolate
Leaves elliptic to ovate or rotund, 2–5 mm long; apparently simple
Stems distinctly flattened and slightly winged
Stems terete or oval to rarely slightly flattened

Stems procumbent; leaves circular to narrow-ovate or oblong, obtuse or acute apically but not pungent, on distinct petiolules up to 5 mm long; calyx pubescent outside; pods on a stipe that is shorter than the calyx

Stems erect and spreading; leaves trullate or triangular to ovate, lanceolate or linear to linear-lanceolate, acute and usually pungent apically, sessile or on distinct petiolules up to 1.5 mm long; calyx glabrous or almost so outside; pods on a stipe that exceeds the calyx
Leaves linear to linear-lanceolate, 1–3 mm wide, on distinct petiolules up to 1.5 mm long; Grampians only
Leaves trullate or triangular to ovate or lanceolate, 2–7 mm wide, sessile or almost so

Small spur on petiole (at leaflet articulation point) present on at least some leaves; stipules spreading to reflexed, inserted on opposite sides of the petiole; leaf length to width ratio >3; wing petals purplish-brown; widespread in southern Victoria (but largely absent in the Otway Ranges)
Petiole lacking spur; stipules recurved to reflexed (and somewhat V-shaped), inserted relatively close to each other; leaf length to width ratio <3; wing petals yellow; Otway Ranges
Upper lobes of calyx c. 0.5 mm longer than lower lobes; keel petals < 6 mm long; style 1–2 mm long; East Gippsland
Upper lobes of calyx 1.5–3 mm longer than lower lobes; keel petals > 6 mm long; style 2.5–6 mm long; Central and Eastern Highlands
Upper surface of leaves usually tuberculate; lower surface of leaves sparsely hairy or glabrous, distinctly concave; leaf margins recurved or revolute
Upper surface of leaves lacking tubercules, or tubercules restricted to margins; lower surface of leaves glabrous to sericeous, usually flat; margins flat or slightly recurved
Stipules less than 1.5 mm long; leaves usually broad-ovate; bracteoles up to 1 mm long, not extending onto the calyx
Stipules more than 1.5 mm long; leaves usually transversely oblong-elliptic; bracteoles more than 2 mm long, extending well onto the calyx
Lower surface of leaves sericeous; bracteoles less than 2 mm long, usually with some hairs; calyx pubescent, hairs sometimes restricted to lobes; north eastern and eastern Victoria

Lower surface of leaves glabrous or with scattered hairs near midrib; bracteoles more than 2 mm long, glabrous; calyx glabrous or with sparsely hairy lobes; southern alps (Lake Mountain, Snowy Range, and Mt Buffalo)
Flowers pinkish-red, over 15 mm long; the standard much shorter than the lower petals
Flowers mostly yellow or orange with red or brown markings, less than 15 mm long; the standard as long as or longer than the lower petals

Flowering pedicels exceeding the basal bracts; bracteoles persistent; erect or procumbent shrub with ultimate branches of the cladodes 2–7 mm wide; young growth lacking large conspicuous scales as above

Flowering pedicels shorter than or scarcely exceeding the basal bracts; bracteoles soon deciduous; rigid erect shrub with ultimate branches of the cladodes (2–)5–14 mm wide; young growth with conspicuous brown scarious ovate scales to 5 mm long at the nodes (to 2 mm long in B. grayi)
Lax, decumbent or sprawling, sparingly branched shrub; ultimate branches of cladodes 2–7 mm wide; pods 2.5–4.5 cm long; coastal heathlands of far East Gippsland
Erect much-branched shrub; ultimate branches of cladodes 2–4 mm wide; pods to 2.5 cm long; widespread, often riparian
Largest cladode scales more than 1 mm wide from mid-rib to margin, with conspicuous branching venation; cladodes with recess at nodes up to 5 mm deep
Cladode scales less than 1 mm wide from midrib to margin, with venation obscure; cladodes lacking distinct recess at nodes (less than 1 mm deep)
